AlternativeForm: barb bhardh-a (if it goes back to beard?)

CommentOnOEDFullSense: burble > bubble > bubbly; The English word can hardly have any actual connection with these, except as a parallel onomatopoeia, expressing the sound made by the agitation, issuing forth, or flowing of a liquid mixed with vesicles of air or gas. Of this the later bubble n. appears to have been either a simple variant or a conscious modification.
Onomatopoeic: the v.n. of action being probably coeval.
